bioghist.p: Rudolf Serkin (1903-1991) was a renowned pianist and teacher. He was born in Bohemia and made his public debut at 12 with the Vienna Philharmonic. From 1918 to 1920 he studied composition with Arnold Schoenberg. Throughout the 1920s and early 1930s he lived in Berlin and performed throughout Europe. With the rise of the Nazi party, Serkin left Berlin for Switzerland. In 1935, he married Irene Busch. In 1936 he launched his solo concert career in the U. S. with the New York Philharmonic under Arturo Toscanini. Shortly after the onset of World War II in 1939, the Serkins and the Busch family emigrated to the United States, where Serkin joined the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia as a piano professor. From 1968 to 1976 he served as Director of the Curtis Institute. In 1951, Serkin and Adolf Busch founded the Marlboro Music School and Festival, and Serkin served as its artistic director from 1952 to 1991.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of professional and personal paper of Rudolf Serkin. The professional papers in the collection relate to his performing career as well as his teaching and administrative work at the Curtis Institute of Music and the Marlboro Festival. Materials related to Serkin's performing career include: programs and reviews (1930s-1980s); correspondence with colleagues, program organizers, fellow musicians, record companies, and fans; itineraries and tour information; appointment calendars; royalty records; and publicity photos and press releases. Curtis Institute materials include: correspondence from faculty, students, and board members; schedules; memos about student and school matters; budgets; programs; and a copy of a commencement speech by Serkin. Materials from the Marlboro Festival include: correspondence; programs and schedules; planning documents, budgets and financial reports; and applications and invitations to perform at the Festival. There are also minutes and memos from professional and cultural organizations with which Serkin was involved, including the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. Among the correspondents in the collection are cellist Pablo Casals, violist Alexander Schneider, violinist Adolf Busch, artistic manager Arthur Judson, and recording executive Goddard Lieberson. Personal papers include: correspondence from friends and family, including his son Peter Serkin; drawings by Serkin's grandchildren; family snapshots; birthday greetings; records related to his farm; household budgets; and financial records. Some of the personal correspondence is in German.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
